newsitem.title: RUSSIA: New Russian air code backs safety, majority stake.
newsitem.headline: New Russian air code backs safety, majority stake.

text.p: Russia has introduced new aviation regulations which will improve passenger safety and assure Russian majority stakes in joint ventures with foreign partners, a Federal Aviation Service (FAS) official said on Tuesday.
Karl Ruppel, an aide to FAS director Gennady Zaitsev, told Reuters the new rules would regulate relations and services by all Russian companies involved in passenger and cargo aviation.
"The main point of the rules is to guarantee safety for passengers who travel by air," Ruppel said.
The Air Code (Vozdushny Kodeks) consists of 137 articles.
Ruppel said the code, which replaces a Soviet version adopted in 1983, would bar majority foreign ownership in new joint ventures. The old rules did not allow foreign majority ownership either.
"The new rules guarantee the Russian side will have 51 percent of shares if they set up a joint venture with foreign partners," Ruppel said.
He said the new code had been based on internationally-agreed standards.
"I think this code could be called the constitution of Russian civil aviation," Ruppel said, adding Russia needed the rules to improve its position on international markets.
"The rules are similar to international regulations," he added.
Russia becomes the eighth country in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) to adopt its own aviation rules.
